summary: This document is a FOIA request submitted by James Robertson, Senior Managing Editor of The National Enquirer, seeking records related to the FBI's investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein for sexual trafficking of minors. The request emphasizes the public interest in the case, particularly in light of Epstein's connections and the favorable treatment he received from the DOJ, as well as the ongoing civil defamation trial involving one of Epstein's victims and Ghislaine Maxwell. This document consists of a series of letters from the FBI to Daniel Novack, representing Radar Online, regarding requests made under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) concerning Jeffrey Epstein. The letters detail the processing of these requests, the exemptions applied to withheld information, and the procedures for appeal and dispute resolution.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Guilty
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to one count of felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Investigation Initiated
events.description: Epstein became the subject of an undercover sex trafficking investigation by Palm Beach police and the FBI.

locations: New York Plaza, New York, NY 10004
keyFacts: James Robertson is requesting records under the Freedom of Information Act regarding Jeffrey Epstein's investigation.
The National Enquirer argues that the information sought is in the public interest and relates to government integrity.
Epstein's connections to prominent figures like Bill Clinton and Prince Andrew are highlighted as part of the investigation's context.
Epstein pled guilty to a single count of soliciting prostitution and served only 13 months in prison.
There is a civil defamation trial involving one of Epstein's victims and Ghislaine Maxwell currently underway.
The FBI has processed multiple FOIA requests from Daniel Novack regarding Jeffrey Epstein.
The documents contain numerous exemptions under FOIA, including those related to law enforcement and national security.
The FBI has indicated that it can neither confirm nor deny the existence of certain records related to watch lists.
The correspondence includes standard responses applicable to all FOIA requests, including information about the FBI's record-keeping practices.
